verses.text: Pay attention, O heavens, and I will speak; let the earth hear the words of my mouth.
verses.comment: Moses calls upon all creation as witnesses to the seriousness and universality of his message, underlining that this song teaches essential truths for all times.

verses.text: Let my teaching fall as rain, and my words descend like dew, like showers on fresh grass, like abundant rain on tender plants.
verses.comment: Rain and dew in Scripture often symbolize God's word nourishing the faithful. There is a sacramental undertone here, as God's word brings life and growth.

verses.text: For I will proclaim the name of the LORD. Ascribe greatness to our God!
verses.comment: To declare God's name is to reveal His character and authority. This foreshadows New Testament insights on the revealed name of God in Jesus (see John 17:6).

verses.text: He is the Rock; His work is perfect, for all His ways are just. A God of faithfulness and without iniquity, righteous and upright is He.
verses.comment: Calling God 'the Rock' denotes stability and dependability. Paul later draws from this theme, linking 'the Rock' to Christ (1 Cor. 10:4).

verses.text: They have dealt corruptly with Him; they are no longer His children because of their blemish; they are a crooked and twisted generation.
verses.comment: Moses denounces Israel’s repeated unfaithfulness, echoed by Jesus’ rebukes of His own generation.

verses.text: Is this how you repay the LORD, O foolish and unwise people? Is He not your Father, who created you, who made you and established you?
verses.comment: Israel is chided for ingratitude. 'Father' here is significant, anticipating New Testament adoption as sons in Christ.

verses.text: Remember the days of old; consider the years of many generations. Ask your father, and he will show you; your elders, and they will tell you.
verses.comment: Tradition and teaching from elders are key for faithful transmission of God's works. The early church emphasized this continuity.

verses.text: When the Most High gave the nations their inheritance, when He separated the sons of man, He set the boundaries of the peoples according to the number of the sons of God.
verses.comment: This verse alludes to divine providence in establishing the nations. 'Sons of God' reflects some ancient manuscripts which point to a heavenly council context. See Dead Sea Scroll variants.

verses.text: For the LORD’s portion is His people, Jacob His allotted inheritance.
verses.comment: God chooses Israel as His treasured people, a theme the apostles apply to the Church (1 Pet. 2:9).

verses.text: He found him in a desert land, in the howling waste of the wilderness; He surrounded him, cared for him, guarded him as the apple of His eye.
verses.comment: 'Apple of His eye' conveys God's intimate love and protection. The Church is later described this way in spiritual writings.

verses.text: Like an eagle stirring up its nest, hovering over its young, spreading out its wings to catch them, bearing them on its pinions—
verses.comment: The image of the eagle suggests tender yet powerful care and protection. Parallels appear in the Exodus and prophetic books.

verses.text: So the LORD alone led him; no foreign god was with him.
verses.comment: Emphasizing monotheism, this verse anticipates New Testament claims about the exclusivity of salvation in Christ (Acts 4:12).

verses.text: He made him ride on the heights of the land and fed him with produce from the fields. He nourished him with honey from the rock and with oil from the flinty crag;
verses.comment: God's abundance in the promised land is a sign of His blessing, prefiguring the spiritual blessings given to believers through the sacraments.

verses.text: Curds from the herd and milk from the flock, with fat of lambs; rams of Bashan and goats, with the finest wheat—and you drank foaming wine, made from the blood of the grape.
verses.comment: 'Blood of the grape' later takes on Eucharistic overtones in Christian interpretation, looking forward to the covenant in Christ’s blood (Matt. 26:27-28).

verses.text: But Jeshurun grew fat and kicked; you grew fat, thick and sleek. Then he forsook God who made him and rejected the Rock of his salvation.
verses.comment: Jeshurun ('the upright') ironically refers to Israel’s privilege turning into complacency. Warning against presumption on God’s grace.

verses.text: They provoked Him to jealousy with strange gods; with abominations they angered Him.
verses.comment: Idolatry is depicted as spiritual infidelity, a theme developed in later prophetic writings.

verses.text: They sacrificed to demons, not God, to gods they had not known, to new gods that had come recently, whom your ancestors had never feared.
verses.comment: Paul draws on this passage to warn that idolatry is demonic in nature. Spiritual discernment is crucial.

verses.text: You neglected the Rock who fathered you; you forgot the God who gave you birth.
verses.comment: 'Gave you birth' is a rare maternal image for God, showing both paternal and maternal aspects to God’s care.

verses.text: The LORD saw it and rejected them, because of the provocation of His sons and His daughters.
verses.comment: Even when rejected, Israel is still called 'His sons and His daughters,' foreshadowing the persistence of God’s covenant.

verses.text: And He said: 'I will hide My face from them, I will see what their end will be, for they are a perverse generation, children in whom is no faithfulness.'
verses.comment: ‘Hiding My face’ indicates withdrawal of favor, symbolizing the reality of spiritual consequences for persistent disobedience.

verses.text: They have made Me jealous with what is not God; they have angered Me with their idols. So I will make them jealous with those who are not a people; I will provoke them with a foolish nation.
verses.comment: Paul interprets this as foreshadowing the Gentiles' inclusion in salvation history, a mysterious plan fully revealed in Christ.

verses.text: For a fire is kindled by My anger, and it burns to the depths of Sheol, devouring the earth and its increase, and setting the foundations of the mountains on fire.
verses.comment: Sheol refers to the realm of the dead. God’s judgment is depicted as cosmic in scope, highlighting His absolute justice.

verses.text: I will heap disasters upon them; I will spend My arrows against them;
verses.comment: ‘Arrows’ are a recurring symbol for divine retribution.

verses.text: They shall be wasted with hunger, consumed by plague and poisonous pestilence; I will send the teeth of beasts against them, with venom of crawling things that creep in the dust.
verses.comment: Punishments include natural disasters, a motif frequent in covenantal warnings.

verses.text: Outside the sword shall make them childless, and inside there shall be terror; both young man and virgin, nursing child with the man of gray hairs.
verses.comment: The severity of judgment falls on all ages, fulfilling covenant curses for unfaithfulness.

verses.text: I said, I would scatter them far away, I would make the memory of them to cease from among mankind,
verses.comment: The threat of exile and national eradication finds later historical echoes in Israel’s captivities.

verses.text: But I feared the taunt of the enemy, lest their adversaries misunderstand, lest they say, 'Our hand is exalted, and the LORD has not done any of this.'
verses.comment: God’s concern for His name and reputation among the nations is a motivation for preserving Israel despite their sins.

verses.text: For they are a nation void of counsel, and there is no understanding in them.
verses.comment: The repeated warnings highlight the need for humble wisdom and repentance.

verses.text: If only they were wise, that they would understand this, and realize what their latter end will be!
verses.comment: Contrasts the foolishness of the people with God’s desire for their conversion and salvation.

verses.text: How could one chase a thousand, and two put ten thousand to flight, unless their Rock had sold them, and the LORD had given them up?
verses.comment: Israel’s military defeats are attributed to divine judgment rather than enemy strength, teaching trust in God’s sovereignty.

verses.text: For their rock is not like our Rock, even our enemies themselves concede.
verses.comment: The inferiority of other nations' gods is emphasized; the singularity of Israel’s God anticipates the role of the one true faith.

verses.text: For their vine is from the vine of Sodom, from the fields of Gomorrah; their grapes are grapes of poison, their clusters are bitter.
verses.comment: ‘Vine’ imagery later becomes central in the teachings of Jesus regarding spiritual fruit (John 15:1-5).

verses.text: Their wine is the venom of serpents and the deadly poison of vipers.
verses.comment: Wickedness brings spiritual death, contrasting with Christ’s life-giving blood in Eucharistic imagery.

verses.text: Is not this laid up in store with Me, sealed up among My treasures?
verses.comment: God keeps account and will repay; the concept of 'storing up' finds a parallel in Christ’s teaching about God as just judge.

verses.text: Vengeance is Mine, and recompense, for the time when their foot shall slip; for the day of their calamity is at hand, and what is destined for them hastens.
verses.comment: Paul quotes this to highlight God’s perfect justice and the importance of leaving vengeance to God.

verses.text: For the LORD will judge His people and have compassion on His servants, when He sees that their strength is gone and there is none remaining, bond or free.
verses.comment: Even in judgment, God’s mercy towards the humble and the afflicted remains, a central theme of Christian hope.

verses.text: Then He will say, 'Where are their gods, the rock in which they took refuge,
verses.comment: God exposes the impotence of false gods, a repeated prophetic theme.

verses.text: who ate the fat of their sacrifices and drank the wine of their drink offering? Let them rise up and help you! Let them be your protection!'
verses.comment: A challenge exposing the vanity of idolatry, a call echoed by the prophets and Christ.

verses.text: See now that I, even I, am He, and there is no god beside Me; I kill and I make alive; I wound and I heal; and there is none who can deliver out of My hand.
verses.comment: Divine sovereignty and exclusivity are at the heart of this confession; Jesus echoes the authority of the Father in the Gospels.

verses.text: For I lift up My hand to heaven and swear, As I live forever,
verses.comment: God’s oath, affirmed on His own life, echoes themes later found in Hebrews.

verses.text: if I sharpen My flashing sword and My hand takes hold on judgment, I will take vengeance on My adversaries and will repay those who hate Me.
verses.comment: The retributive justice of God is a common prophetic and apocalyptic theme, yet tempered by mercy elsewhere.

verses.text: I will make My arrows drunk with blood, and My sword shall devour flesh— with the blood of the slain and the captives, from the long-haired heads of the enemy.’
verses.comment: Symbolic of complete judgment, also found in the eschatological visions of Revelation.

verses.text: Rejoice, O nations, with His people! For He will avenge the blood of His servants, and will render vengeance on His adversaries, and will atone for the land of His people.
verses.comment: This verse is cited in the New Testament to illustrate the plan for all peoples to be joined to God’s people; the notion of atonement for the land prefigures the redemptive work of Christ.

verses.text: So Moses came with Joshua son of Nun and recited all the words of this song in the hearing of the people.
verses.comment: The leadership transition from Moses to Joshua models apostolic succession: a continuation of authority for God’s people.

verses.text: When Moses had finished speaking all these words to all Israel,
verses.comment: This marks the end of Moses' prophetic song for this generation.

verses.text: he said to them: 'Take to heart all the words by which I warn you today, so that you may command them to your children, so that they may obey all the words of this law.'
verses.comment: Command to hand on the faith intact is foundational, just as the apostles heed Jesus’ commission.

verses.text: For it is no empty word for you, but your very life, and by this word you will live long in the land you are crossing the Jordan to possess.
verses.comment: Obedience to God’s revelation brings life; in the New Covenant this finds its fulfillment in living by Christ’s words.

verses.text: That very day the LORD spoke to Moses,
verses.comment: God’s timing is perfect and intentional, marking the importance of Moses’ final instructions.

verses.text: 'Go up to this mountain of the Abarim, Mount Nebo, which is in the land of Moab, opposite Jericho, and view the land of Canaan, which I am giving to the people of Israel for a possession.'
verses.comment: Moses is permitted to see but not enter the Promised Land, illustrating the reality of falling short through disobedience—even for great leaders.

verses.text: 'There you shall die on the mountain that you go up and be gathered to your people, as Aaron your brother died on Mount Hor and was gathered to his people.'
verses.comment: 'Gathered to your people' implies a hope in life after death, an important progressive revelation in Scripture.

verses.text: Because you broke faith with Me in the midst of the people of Israel at the waters of Meribah Kadesh, in the wilderness of Zin, and did not uphold My holiness among the people of Israel.
verses.comment: Moses’ punishment exemplifies the principle that leaders are held to a higher standard—a pattern for pastoral responsibility.

verses.text: For you shall see the land before you, but you shall not go there, into the land that I am giving to the people of Israel.'
verses.comment: The chapter ends with a generational transition and the solemn reminder that fulfillment of God’s promises is ultimately His work, calling for trust in His mysterious providence.
